ags:resource.dc:title: Extension provision in organic agriculture: the case of Crete, Greece and Baden-Wurttemberg, Germany [Thesis (M.Sc.)]

dc:description.dcterms:abstract: With the growth of organically cultivated area in Europe, input intensive conventional farming systems are increasingly replaced by knowledge intensive organic ones. Developing and performing appropriate interventions in organic agriculture (OA) is based on a complex learning progress for all: researchers, extension workers and farmers. Methods in extension for organic farmers have to be adapted accordingly and the quality standards deserve further consideration. Currently, extension offering for organic farmers in Europe is ranging from public governmental and private institutions over commercial expert consultants to farmer self-help groups. The performance of extension is varying considerably in terms of quality and methods. The aim of the study is to explore the extension services offered in the field of OA especially with a view to sustainability in two contrasting European regions, Baden-Württemberg (BW), Germany and the island of Crete, Greece. Research was focused on the institutional settings of extension services and the specific needs in terms of expertise and extension methodology of OA extension agents (EAs). Sixteen in-depth interviews were conducted with representatives of relevant providers of extension and vocational training in the field of OA and analyzed qualitatively.
